excerpt: Those annoying IKEA product tags and information stickers that seem determined to stay put forever. Here's how to get rid of them once and for all.
text: We’ve all been there. You’ve just assembled your beautiful new IKEA furniture, and now you’re faced with those annoying price tags and information stickers that seem determined to stay put forever. This exact problem sparked a lively discussion on Reddit recently, with dozens of users sharing their tried-and-true methods for tackling these stubborn adhesives. Before you resign yourself to living with them (or worse, scratching up your new purchase), check out these proven methods from Redditors who’ve successfully conquered this common furniture dilemma. Heat Methods Heat is often the gentlest first approach, as it softens the adhesive without requiring any chemicals. Hair dryer or heat gun: This was one of the most upvoted suggestions. As Redditor aceward explains, “A hair dryer or heat gun should soften the glue enough for you to peel them off easily. Just not too much heat in one spot for too long.” This method received enthusiastic endorsement from multiple users. See this demo from IKEAhacker reader Mary Cahill. Wait for the last satisfying bit! Chemical Solutions If heat alone doesn’t do the trick, Redditors recommend several products that can break down stubborn adhesive: Rubbing alcohol/isopropyl alcohol: “Remove any remaining residue with alcohol,” advises user Gold-en-Hind. Another Redditor, simply stated “Rubbing Alcohol” as their go-to solution. Goo Gone: A dedicated adhesive remover that received multiple mentions. One Redditor shared: “I’ve had the same bottle for a decade because I only need a drop. I just put some in the cap and dip the corner of a sponge or paper towel and it gets all the crap left by stickers off.” WD-40: Another user kept it simple with “WD40” – a household staple that’s effective for breaking down adhesives. Sticker remover spray: “There is an actual product called sticker remover spray. It can be a bit messy, but if the sticker is paper rather than plastic-based, it’s the only good way, imho,” according to a user. Furniture polish: One creative solution came from MikeTerrapin: “Furniture polish (Mr. Sheen spray type) can help remove stickers, although it works better on some than others. I used to work in a bookshop and we used it there for taking promotional stickers off books.” Acetone: “Acetone and a blade,” recommends Ohz85 for particularly stubborn cases (use with caution). Tools and Techniques Having the right tools can make a big difference: Plastic ruler or scraper: User miasparkes shared their efficient method: “I use a plastic ruler to remove the sticker and spray on wall cleanup to remove the glue. Easy as. Literally done in under a minute.” Plastic razor scraper: One Redditor linked to these specialized tools designed for removing adhesives without scratching surfaces. Adhesive tape method: “I use tape and stick it on the residue. It takes a while but I can get everything off that way,” explains curly-sue99, adding, “For me, it was better than rubbing alcohol.” Step-by-Step Process For Removing Stubborn IKEA Stickers For best results, follow these steps: Start with heat to soften the adhesive Carefully peel off as much of the sticker as possible Apply your chosen adhesive remover to any remaining residue Gently remove residue with a plastic scraper Clean the area with a mild soap and water A Word of Caution Redditor Perlusion offered this important advice: “Taking off those stickers is not good for items you want to sell back to IKEA in a while. They can’t take them back if you are missing those.” Something to consider if you might return the item. Community Frustrations The thread revealed this is a common pain point among IKEA customers. “I hate IKEA for this,” wrote one frustrated user named oopiicaa, receiving 30 upvotes from like-minded shoppers. Another Redditor, hollow4hollow, expressed what many were thinking: “IKEA really needs to rethink its sticker recipe. It would be so easy to get the residue-free kind instead. I have cleaned so many gummy, hairy spots on furniture and storage.” With these community-approved methods in your arsenal, you can enjoy your sleek, sticker-free IKEA furniture without the frustration of stubborn adhesive residue. What’s your go-to method for removing persistent stickers? Let us know in the comments!
html:
We’ve all been there. You’ve just assembled your beautiful new IKEA furniture, and now you’re faced with those annoying price tags and information stickers that seem determined to stay put forever.

This exact problem sparked a lively discussion on Reddit recently, with dozens of users sharing their tried-and-true methods for tackling these stubborn adhesives.

Before you resign yourself to living with them (or worse, scratching up your new purchase), check out these proven methods from Redditors who’ve successfully conquered this common furniture dilemma.

Heat Methods

Heat is often the gentlest first approach, as it softens the adhesive without requiring any chemicals.

Hair dryer or heat gun: This was one of the most upvoted suggestions. As Redditor aceward explains, “A hair dryer or heat gun should soften the glue enough for you to peel them off easily. Just not too much heat in one spot for too long.” This method received enthusiastic endorsement from multiple users.

See this demo from IKEAhacker reader Mary Cahill. Wait for the last satisfying bit!

Chemical Solutions

If heat alone doesn’t do the trick, Redditors recommend several products that can break down stubborn adhesive:

Rubbing alcohol/isopropyl alcohol: “Remove any remaining residue with alcohol,” advises user Gold-en-Hind. Another Redditor, simply stated “Rubbing Alcohol” as their go-to solution.

Goo Gone: A dedicated adhesive remover that received multiple mentions. One Redditor shared: “I’ve had the same bottle for a decade because I only need a drop. I just put some in the cap and dip the corner of a sponge or paper towel and it gets all the crap left by stickers off.”

WD-40: Another user kept it simple with “WD40” – a household staple that’s effective for breaking down adhesives.

Sticker remover spray: “There is an actual product called sticker remover spray. It can be a bit messy, but if the sticker is paper rather than plastic-based, it’s the only good way, imho,” according to a user.

Furniture polish: One creative solution came from MikeTerrapin: “Furniture polish (Mr. Sheen spray type) can help remove stickers, although it works better on some than others. I used to work in a bookshop and we used it there for taking promotional stickers off books.”

Acetone: “Acetone and a blade,” recommends Ohz85 for particularly stubborn cases (use with caution).

Tools and Techniques

Having the right tools can make a big difference:

Plastic ruler or scraper: User miasparkes shared their efficient method: “I use a plastic ruler to remove the sticker and spray on wall cleanup to remove the glue. Easy as. Literally done in under a minute.”

Plastic razor scraper: One Redditor linked to these specialized tools designed for removing adhesives without scratching surfaces.

Adhesive tape method: “I use tape and stick it on the residue. It takes a while but I can get everything off that way,” explains curly-sue99, adding, “For me, it was better than rubbing alcohol.”

Step-by-Step Process For Removing Stubborn IKEA Stickers

For best results, follow these steps:

  1. Start with heat to soften the adhesive
  2. Carefully peel off as much of the sticker as possible
  3. Apply your chosen adhesive remover to any remaining residue
  4. Gently remove residue with a plastic scraper
  5. Clean the area with a mild soap and water

A Word of Caution

Redditor Perlusion offered this important advice: “Taking off those stickers is not good for items you want to sell back to IKEA in a while. They can’t take them back if you are missing those.” Something to consider if you might return the item.

Community Frustrations

The thread revealed this is a common pain point among IKEA customers. “I hate IKEA for this,” wrote one frustrated user named oopiicaa, receiving 30 upvotes from like-minded shoppers.

Another Redditor, hollow4hollow, expressed what many were thinking: “IKEA really needs to rethink its sticker recipe. It would be so easy to get the residue-free kind instead. I have cleaned so many gummy, hairy spots on furniture and storage.”

With these community-approved methods in your arsenal, you can enjoy your sleek, sticker-free IKEA furniture without the frustration of stubborn adhesive residue.

What’s your go-to method for removing persistent stickers? Let us know in the comments!
